abstract.p: New visitor center at Pont du Gard, Roman aqueduct that spans Gardon River between Nimes and Avignon, France, opens; photos (M)

block.p: Built in the early part of the first century, the 150-foot-high Pont du Gard spanning the Gardon River between Nimes and Avignon crowns a stunning engineering feat. Built in the early part of the first century, the 150-foot-high Pont du Gard spanning the Gardon River between Nimes and Avignon crowns a stunning engineering feat. The stone aqueduct supplied water from the source of the Eure at Uzes to the thermal baths and fountains of the Roman colony of Nimes, more than 31 miles away, until the early fifth century.

Awarded Unesco World Heritage status in 1985, the Pont du Gard has attracted 1,250,000 visitors a year despite a lack of visitor facilities. Now, a recently completed $27 million project has filled that need.

Two new buildings housing the visitor center are on either side of the Gardon River, out of view of the monument. Le Portal presents hands-on archaeological and engineering projects for children and a film that recounts the aqueduct's history with contemporary images. A research library and a permanent exhibition, ''Man, Stone and Water in the Mediterranean Landscape,'' will open in January. In the second building, a 245-seat auditorium, La Baume, is concealed in a former quarry.

All cultural events and demonstrations are presented in French, English, German and Spanish. Parking facilities have been moved farther away from the aqueduct, creating new garden areas in the 400-acre setting. A former highway has been transformed into a pedestrian promenade that is accessible by wheelchair and stroller, as are the new or renovated restaurants, snack bars and Provencal boutiques.

Admission to the Pont du Gard remains free. Entrance fees to Le Portal and La Baume are $3.25 to $4.50; under 5 free. Open daily June 1 to Aug. 31, 9:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.; Sept. 1 to May 31 8:30 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. Information: (33-4) 66.37.50.99.
